bboxes.raw_text:
TUCSON (AP) = Roy Wilkins,
national director of the National
Association for Advancement Of
Colored People (NAACP), told the
Tucson Press Club that the Con-
gress of Racial Equality was
responsible for the picketing at
the Republican National Con-
vention and he added, GORE
has internal problems"


After hearing Wilkins COM
ments, Roy Twitty. local CORE
president, walked out.


"CORE is what is facetioulsy
known as a loosely knit organ
ization," Wilkins said. while
the San Francisco chapter was
picketing the convention the
New York leaders we're mutter-
ing in their beer or what
ever they drink"

CORE Leader w uIks
Out On wilkins

PHILADELPHIA (NPD Mayor
James H. j. Tate reported last
week that the recent race riots
that rocked North Philadelphia
will cost the Getty of Brotherly
Love- a total of $4.2 million,
and that he will have to make
some changes" in the program
of several city departments to
avert having to increase taxes
to abs orb the cost.


The biggest item in the riot
expense. the mayor said, is a
claim of about SIS million made
on the city by some 500 shop
keepers for damages to their
properties. He said the next
biggest item is SIS million for
police and park guard overtime,
food for these men and especial
equipment" including helmets.

Detectives Norm OComor and
Bob Manning said a very thin
Negro man and a heavily built
white woman took 1882 from
Ben Brothers Market, 1645 E.
Van Buren, Friday.


Both welding pistols. used ad-
hesive tape to tie the owners,
Mr.. and Mrs. Ben C. Ong, and
three customers a boy, about
IA; a girl about 4: and Richard
Henry. owner ofCometition Mo-
tors. l705 E. Van Buren,.


The youngsters quickly worked
themselves free after the rob-
bers left, police said. The adults,
gagged by strips Of tape. were
unable even to ask the children
for help and could only watch and
groan as the youngsters ran from
the store.


The Ongs and Henry were
working slowly at the tape that
held them when deliveryman Paul
Stevenson, 1924 N. 30th Drive,
entered the store, discovered
them, and freed them.

Robert l.. Carter announced.


NAACP Executive Director
Roy Wilkins hailed the successful
termination of the case and ex-
pressed confidence that the As
sociation will soon regain its
position of leadership" in Ala
bama.


An order from the Circuit Curt
of Montgomery County. handed
down on Sept. 10, dissolved a
permanent Injunction banning
NAACP activity in the state and
cleared the way for reorganiza-
tion of local Association units
to resume the NAACP civil rights
program in Alabama.

NEW YORK = The National
Association for the Advancement
of Colored People, barred by an
Alabama court Injunction from
operating in that state since 1856,
will soon resume activity in the
only state where no local or
ganization exists.


Papers registering the NAACP
as an OUT of-state corporation,
the first step towards resumption
of activity, we're filed with the
Alabama Secretary of State and
the State Department of Revenue
in Montgomery. Wednesday. Sept.
%, NAACP General Counsel
